title: How do I stop my ex-husband's debt collectors from calling me for payment?
question: In 2005, my husband molested my daughter and I wanted to be divorced immediately. I had to wait for his juvenile and criminal cases to be settled before I could get my divorce. My ex omitted his credit card debt from the settlement so I didn't know about it. A year after he went into prison, cc collections started calling me for payment (more than $18K). I can't get them to stop. They say my name is also on the card. I hate credit cards and stopped using them altogether after he left my house. He is narcissistic and angry, vindictive, etc. He left me and the kids destitute... this isn't the only financial abuse he has committed towards me. Please help!!!
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Criminal charges for identity theft,Spousal debt,Marriage
answers:
The divorce agreement, decree or judgment supposedly settled the rights and obligations between you and the former spouse. However, it does not change the obligations each of you had with third parties who were not in Court when you got the divorce.

The ex-spouse may refuse to make payments to credit card companies, car financing companies, mortgage companies, etc. Your ex may even file for Bankruptcy.

Depending on the law in your State you may have an action against the ex-spouse, and you may even be able to sue the ex-spouse if they file for Bankruptcy and have their obligation to you declared “non-dischargeable”.

Unfortunately the divorce or the ex’s Bankruptcy does not relieve you of any obligations you had to these third parties.

See a lawyer right away!

He may have committed identity theft against you, if he used your name and credit without your authorization to open the account(s). Please see my legal guide on Avvo, which I have linked below. It has step-by-step instructions that you should follow and several links that you will need to not only discover any and all false accounts but also stop them from contacting you and harming your credit. I'd recommend you print the legal guide and use it as a checklist. Do not pay a penny if these are not debts that you authorized and be sure to use certified mail, return receipt requested, because debt collectors frequently deny receiving correspondence.

I would suggest you run your credit report to see if these creditors are claiming that you owe these debts. You may follow the link below to obtain a free annual copy of your credit report.

The fact that your ex husband may have been the only person to have used the cards, or that he is a jerk, or that he didn't disclose the debt in the divorce is completely irrelevant to the issue of whether you are legally responsible for paying on the card. If you signed the credit application, the creditor can sue you to collect the debt.

To stop the calls, obtain contact information from the caller - name, phone number, whether they are the orginal creditor, and most important, mailing address. Tell them to stop calling & follow up with a letter saying the same thing. You have certain rights if the creditor continues to call you after you have told them to stop, but if you are legally responsible for paying the debt, the creditor may exercise their rights by suing you to collect on the debt.

Hope this perspective helps!
